ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Passenger traffic and fares)


    1. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Communications (a) what was the average monthly number of bus commuters prior to the recent increase in bus fares; (b) what was the number of commuters for the first month after the increase; (c) what was the increased net profit of the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited for that month; and (d) basing on this figure of net profit as an average monthly net profit, if the company will meet its budget, as assessed prior to the implementation of the increased fares, to replace old buses, to provide other benefits for its workers, etc.

Column: 242



    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I regret to inform the hon. Member for Anson that neither the Singapore Bus Service Ltd., the Registry of Vehicles nor the Mass Transit Study Unit maintain statistics on the actual number of bus commuters at any one time. The closest estimate regarding passenger traffic handled would be through the number of tickets sold and daily collections made. As many as 1.75 million tickets may be sold per day, ROV is at present collecting statistics on the breakdown of fares collected by the SBS, but due to the large amount of data involved it will take some time before the figures are available. I am glad to announce however, that the Mass Transit Study Unit is at present engaged in a Bus Passenger Count Survey to supplement the data collected by ROV. It is estimated that the survey

Column: 243

which began in January this year will be completed by end of May.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on the basis of unaudited figures submitted by SBS of the fares collected for the period 15th January to 9th February, 1974 (26 days) before the increase in fares, the average daily fare takings arrived at was $268,187. Between 10th February up to 7th March, 1974, for a similar period of 26 days after the bus fare increase became effective, the average daily fare takings rose to $349,140 or an increase of 30 per cent.

    On the basis of just one month's operations after the increase in bus fares, it is somewhat early to talk of profits. One may, however, venture to say that with the increased takings SBS should be able to cope with its increasing expenditure for 1974-75 and to carry out its programme to replace its old buses in accordance with the requirements of the Ministry, provide for better benefits for workers and generally to improve the standard of its services, hereafter.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, can the Minister promise that there will be no further increase of fares?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, with all the best possible will in the world, that promise cannot be made because the bus company runs on oil fuel and that is not within our control. As everybody knows, the whole world waits to hear whether the oil prices will be increased.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I want to know whether the profits of the bus company by that time will be reduced or increased.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, I cannot proceed further on that matter. If there are any details which the Member would like to ask, I will be pleased to supply.

    Encik Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, if it is too early to talk about profits, then I would like to talk about losses. Will the Hon. Minister for Communications authorise bus fare

Column: 244

increases each time the bus owners put their hands up in horror and say that they have made losses? And since the bus owners know that the Government is most unwilling to operate the bus service lest it has to subsidise the operations, will the Hon. Minister assure us that he will not be taken for a ride? How do we know that he has not been taken for a ride by the SBS? This is a test question, as further questions have yet to come.

    Can the Hon. Minister inform us whether the SBS is the only business concern, most unfortunately a private monopoly controlling a public service under its wing, which is privileged by Government intervention to wipe off operating losses and to raise capital at the public's expense? Profits, virtually, guaranteed quite a risk-free business, is this not fortunate?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, that is a long-winded statement rather than a question because most of the questions posed have already been answered. The Member is just repeating himself.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I develop on the question raised by the Member for Anson? I am not happy with the reply given by the Minister when he said that further rises in fares would depend on a subsequent rise in oil prices. I think he must have read the newspaper report -

    Mr Speaker: What is your supplementary question, Dr Ong?

    Dr Ong Leong Boon: My question is this. I do not think that bus fares should be dependent so much upon international oil prices. There are other considerations besides the price of oil, and I maintain that we should not just use the price of oil as a reason for any further hikes in bus fares. Will the Minister please comment?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, apparently the Member did not follow my oral answers. It has already been indicated that the Government is not going to allow a bus fare revision without making

Column: 245

sure that the management of the company is able to account for its revenue and expenditure to the satisfaction of the Government. So it does not necessarily follow that the company is allowed to revise the bus fares by just putting hands up, as alleged by the Member for Kallang. They `have to justify it. It is too early now to talk of further bus fare increases when the new fares have just operated for only one month.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Sir, will the Minister be able to say whether there has been any effect on the takings of the SBS because of the operation of the supplementary transport service?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I think there has been some effect on the takings of the SBS as a result of the inauguration of the supplementary bus transport service.

    Mr Conceicao: Mr Speaker, Sir, in that case, does the Minister not think that such competition will spur the SBS into making a better provision for its service? And the result should be that the Minister might consider giving more encouragement to this supplementary transport service.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: When we launched the supplementary public transport service, we did say that we would issue as many as 1,000 licences, of which 600 would be for school buses and 400 for lorries. The number of applications that have been received and approved was about 300. So another 700 licences could still he issued, provided the applicants would send in their applications.

SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Prosecutions for smoky buses)


    2. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications the number of prosecutions during the four months from November 1973 to February 1974 inclusive against the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited

Column: 246

for using buses emitting smoke beyond the permissible limit on public roads; and the combined figures for the component companies of the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited for the corresponding periods during the five years before the amalgamation.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I first mention that statistics on the number of cases of buses emitting excessive smoke are kept by the Traffic Police, of the Ministry of Home Affairs, and not the Registry of Vehicles. Unfortunately, as statistics for such cases prior to April 1970 (i.e., start of the three-year White Paper plan for the reorganisation of the Motor Transport Service of Singapore) were not kept separately, it would be necessary for the Traffic Police to manually run through their records of every case of all traffic offences to obtain the statistics prior to April 1970. I therefore regret I am not able to provide statistics for five years prior to amalgamation, as requested by the Member for Kallang at present.

    However, from the statistics made available by the Traffic Police the number of SBS buses booked for smoky exhausts for the four months since it began operations in November last year, as compared to the number of buses of the three former bus companies booked for the same offence between April 1970 and October 1973, is as follows:-

Column: 247

cases where action is pending, those where composition has been offered but not yet accepted, those where composition has been offered and accepted, and those which have been prosecuted. I believe the Member wants the number of prosecutions. The Traffic Police are unable to give the figures of those cases which have been prosecuted only. However, SBS itself has on record that, from November last year to February this year, they were prosecuted on six occasions and paid out $54,465 in composition for smoky exhausts.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Sir, my question is on policy, and policy is normally the same over a period of time. Therefore, I wish to take the Minister back to memory lane, a little way back in time. With your permission, Sir, may I just quote a little from the Government White Paper (Cmd. 21 of 1970) to assist the Minister in his reply to my question.

    `On 31st March, 1970, the Prime Minister launched an all-out Anti-pollution Campaign, which inter alia, aimed at eradication of the smoky exhausts of motor vehicles. As this drive will have many significant repercussions, including the jacking-up not only of standards of performance and maintenance of vehicles but a general overhaul of the public transport services now existing, this Anti-pollution drive can be regarded as being the starting point for the first ever comprehensive reorganisation of the motor transport service of Singapore.'

So I would like to know what has gone foul. The air has gone foul, I know. Bus service has also gone foul. When will the second campaign begin in earnest?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: The answer, Mr Speaker, Sir, is that the first campaign is still on.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: But who could believe that the campaign is still on?

    Mr Speaker: Encik Aziz, next question.

SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Unroadworthy buses)


    3. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications how many buses of the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited were certified as not roadworthy and their use considered dangerous to the general public, the passengers, the drivers and the conductors.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, all public service vehicles, including buses, are required to undergo inspection by the Registry of Vehicles (ROV) once every six months. They are summoned for such inspection according to a schedule drawn up by the ROV. At these half-yearly inspections, the following are the main items checked: -

    (a) Steering;

    (b) Brakes;

    (c) Lighting;

    (d) Tyres;

    (e) Exhaust;

    (f) Chassis, Body and Suspension

    (g) Engine and Transmission

    (h) Accessories - e.g, rear view mirror, windscreen wiper, horn, speedometer;

    (i) General - e.g, impending failure of the vehicle or any of its equipment or fittings, condition of seating, paint work, bodywork and general condition.

    Any bus which does not meet the minimum standards at these inspections is required to have the defects rectified and be presented again for re-inspection. There have been instances of buses having to be presented several times for re-inspection before being certified fit for use on the road. Sometimes, buses with serious defects are ordered to be scrapped.

    Since the Singapore Bus Service Ltd, began operations in November last year and is a carry-over of operations from the three bus companies, a total of 1,047 of its buses were scheduled by the ROV for the half-yearly inspections

Column: 249

up to the end of last month, February. Of these, 778 buses passed the inspections and were certified fit. Of the other 269, about 215 did not appear for inspection. This sometimes happens when a bus is undergoing repair or overhaul. In such cases, the ROV usually summons the bus for inspection again after one month. About 7 per cent of these buses which were summoned and appeared for inspection did not pass for a variety of defects. The owners were required to have the defects rectified and to present them again for reinspection. None of SBS's buses has, since 1st November last year, been found by the ROV at the inspections to be so unroadworthy that they had to be scrapped.

    It should be stated, however, that 107 buses out of a total registered fleet of 2,081 under the name of SBS are officially laid-up, i.e, these 107 buses or 5.1 per cent are taken off the roads because they are either unroadworthy due to being badly damaged beyond repair or have exceeded the permissible age limit for public buses. They will be replaced under the replacement programme of 400 buses within three years from 1st November, 1973.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, if I am to rely on statistics, there will be hardly any supplementary questions. Anyway, what is the explanation for the frequency of buses falling apart and condemned to the yard? Will the Minister for Communications bear the consequences of allowing unroadworthy vehicles on public roads, or will it be the ROV?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Sir, explanation has already been given as to the reasons why SBS would appear to be in difficulties and the efforts that are being made to put them right. It is no use for the Member for Kallang to repeat this matter over and over again.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Sir, one last supplementary question, as public safety is of great importance. Is there a list of authorised private motor workshops or repairers which the SBS can patronise

Column: 250

for mechanical inspections of its buses, in lieu of inspection by the ROV? And is this the most satisfactory arrangement?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Once again, Mr Speaker, Sir, oral answers have been given to the hon. Member in which it has been indicated that SBS invited private motor repairers to deal with the buses. So I think I should leave it to them.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker. Sir, may I make this point for the benefit of hon. Members? The Government does not wish to be a protector of the Singapore Bus Service Ltd. It is put to the task of explaining the difficulties of SBS, because we have afforded it a licence. And because we have afforded it a licence, a certain rise in the rates of bus fares.

    If Members feel that the matter should be more thoroughly debated because they are not satisfied with just answers to supplementary questions, then I suggest that they put down a formal motion for a thorough debate on the problems of public transport. I would urge this course because this obviously is a subject which not only concerns hon. Members of this House but also the people who buy 11 million tickets every day. It may be 500,000 or 700,000 people who travel on these buses. Perhaps that may be a more satisfactory way of dealing with the problem.

    But I would like to give the Member for Kallang this advice. If he thinks that SBS is such a good buy because it is guaranteed 8 per cent with no entrepreneurial risk, I suggest he buys into SBS. The Government is unwilling. The Member for Kallang can raise the funds and buy into SBS.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, in due course of time, I shall move a motion. I am now only gathering information on how the SBS is run and how it is supervised by the ROV.

    Mr Speaker, let me inform this House that I am an ordinary worker, and there is no question of my buying the SBS,

Column: 251

or even one-quarter of it. The Prime Minister knows me, and also my financial status.

LICENSING OF GOODS VEHICLES
(Reasons for delay)


    4. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Communications the reasons that account for the long delay in the licensing of goods-carrying vehicles for road use, and whether he will direct the Registrar of Vehicles to speed up the processing of such applications in order to avoid shortage of such vehicles.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, there should be no delay on the part of the Registry of Vehicles in licensing goods vehicles, if the proper document, i.e. the weight certificate of the goods vehicle, is available to determine its maximum laden weight for purpose of registration. Unfortunately, such proper documents are not available for a large number of imported used or re-conditioned goods vehicles. For such cases, the ROV has requested the local agent to check these vehicles against their manufacturers' specifications and to issue a certificate which is acceptable for registration. For the services performed, a fee of $100 for each vehicle inspected is levied by the agent.

    Since March, 1973, the agent has issued 987 such certificates for goods vehicles inspected by them. In addition, ROV has, since August, 1973, accepted 152 goods vehicles for registration based on the submission of an extract of registration particulars or plating certificate from the country of origin. The latter measure was undertaken to expedite the registration process. As at 9th March, 1974, the number of vehicles on the waiting list for issue of maximum laden weight certificate by the agent is 227. It has been estimated that the agent could issue up to 20 certificates a week.

    It should be stated that on 28th March last year, the Registrar of Vehicles did inform representatives of leading importers of used goods vehicles of the need for proper documents to support the registration and licensing of such

Column: 252

vehicles. Having these proper documents means the importers need not depend on the certificate issued by the agent and the registration process could then proceed without any delay.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, the first supplementary question is: should we not let the importers know in all such cases that they should try to get the weight certificate from the suppliers? Secondly, if the checking is being done by private firms, how do we ensure that there is no irregularity, and that all applications are processed on the basis of first come first served? Because I have heard of cases where people who apply later have yet got their certificates earlier.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I have already explained, Mr Speaker, Sir, that importers have been told to get the proper documents. If they fail to, whoever buys it is just asking for delay and trouble. If there are instances where the applications were delayed, although they were put in much earlier but were not certified till much later, I would appreciate it if the Member would report such known cases to the Registrar of Vehicles for an investigation to be made.

HAWKERS
(Registration and resiting)


    5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how many hawkers have been registered and how many of them have been resited; (b) how many cases are still under consideration; and (c) if those hawkers affected at development sites will be granted alternative sites until such time as the developments are completed.

    The Minister of State for the Environment (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are a total of 32,141 registered hawkers. Of this number, 25,915 hawkers are licensed by the Ministry of the Environment, 6,001 are under the register of the Housing and Development Board, and the rest by PSA, JTC, and others. Of the 32,000 hawkers, about 14,800 are in markets,

Column: 253

hawker centres and other premises. The rest are in pitches at roadsides, backlanes and vacant lots. Since the construction of new hawker centres by the Ministry of the Environment, 470 street hawkers have been resited by the Ministry and more will be resited in due course as new hawker centres are ready.

    In the recent licensing exercise of bona fide hawkers, 8,264 applications were considered, of which 7,457 were issued with new licences and 807 were rejected, i.e. less than 10 per cent were rejected as they were not bona fide hawkers. There are still 17 appeal cases under consideration.

    On the question of hawkers affected by development, our policy and that of 1-1DB is to give priority to those bona fide hawkers who are affected by development. They are either resited temporarily on an alternative site or moved into another hawker centre if there is vacancy.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy: Mr Speaker, Sir, my question is this: will the hawkers affected by development be granted alternative site or not? That is what I want to know.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last part of my answer, I have clearly stated that they are either resited temporarily on an alternative site or moved into another hawker centre if there is vacancy.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is doing a wonderful job in resiting the hawkers into various hawker centres. I wonder if the Minister realises that the hawkers at Alkaff Avenue in Potong Pasir should be resited, because they are selling their goods at reasonable prices and they are well supported by members of the community.

    Mr Speaker: What is the Member's question?

    Mr Baptist: The question is, will these hawkers be put into hawker centres, or whether a hawker centre will be built at Alkaff Avenue in Potong Pasir?

Column: 254



    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know what is the intention of the hon. Member. But as far as the Hawker's Department is concerned, the position has been regularised by now, i.e, most of the hawkers have been issued with licences to hawk at allocated places. In the case of the place which the Member has mentioned unless the hawkers are affected by redevelopment projects, I do not think the Hawkers' Department will disturb them, unless there is a good reason for the Member to suggest resiting them to any other place.

    Mr Baptist: Mr Speaker, Sir, most certainly, because hawking does affect the environment in the present place in which the hawkers are situated.

BUS SHELTERS AND BUS BAYS
(Construction costs)


    6. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) what is the total cost to date for the construction of bus shelters and bus bays; (b) what is the current value of the lands on which bus shelters and bus bays have been constructed; and (c) if in future expenditure of public funds for the purpose of constructing bus shelters and bus bays will only be incurred when the Government has direct or indirect rights and interests in the bus services.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total cost of the construction of bus shelters and bus bays for the seven years from 1967 to 1973 was $2,312,000. I am afraid that records prior to 1967 are not available.

    The current values of lands vary considerably between urban, sub-urban and rural areas, and also from site to site. It is, therefore, not easy to calculate the land values for the 420 bus bays and 1,480 bus shelters which now exist. Bus bays are provided to prevent the traffic flow from being disrupted by buses waiting at bus stops, whilst bus shelters are constructed for the convenience and protection of bus commuters. These are services which Government will continue to provide.

Column: 255



    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Hon. Minister for Law and National Development consider such expenditure of public funds as a subsidy?

    Mr Barker: I do not think so, unless the Member himself thinks so. It is not only the buses that use the roads but also other vehicles like taxis, private vehicles and lorries. As for bus bays, if there were none, there will be more traffic jams, and passengers waiting to board the bus, particularly school children, are in fact better protected when there is a bus bay. And as for bus shelters, surely the Member for Kallang does not want his constituents or my constituents to be exposed to the sun and rain?

    If the suggestion is that we should charge the bus company the cost of bus bays and bus shelters, this might get them into further trouble and, as it were, perhaps lead to their bankruptcy. But it has not been the policy of Government to charge the bus company. There is a little history behind it because there were so many bus companies before, but now there is one. In the same way, we do not charge taxis for parking at a taxi stand.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, Sir, is it not common practice for a profit-making enterprise to provide, at its own expense, the necessary infrastructure for its business operations?

    Mr Barker: Yes, but in their own premises and for their own equipment. However, these bus shelters are not necessarily used only by persons who board the buses. There is nothing to prevent any of the Members here taking shelter at a bus shelter. But, of course, if anyone parks at a bus bay, then he will be in trouble.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am quite impressed with the reply given by the Minister for National Development. However, will he agree with me if I say that we are, in fact, not constructing enough bus shelters and bus bays for the convenience of the public? Will he, therefore, give an

Column: 256

assurance that this Government will continue to construct more bus bays and bus shelters?

    Mr Barker: Sir, I can assure the Member that more and more bus shelters and bus bays will be built. As I have pointed out, in the last seven or eight years more than $2 million have been spent on them. More will be spent this year and in the coming years. But as the Member realises, there are priorities for other projects, and if he can impress on the Minister for Finance that more money should be provided for this purpose, I will be happy to build more bus shelters and bus bays.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, Sir, I must congratulate the Hon. Minister for Law and National Development. That is the best answer I have received so far. If it is just for the SBS -objection. Otherwise he is free to build as many bus shelters as he wants to for the convenience of the public.

    Mr Ong Teng Cheong (Kim Kent): Mr Speaker, Sir, speaking of subsidy, I was wondering whether the Minister would consider requiring statutory bodies, such as the Housing and Development Board, the Jurong Town Corporation, as well as private estate developers, to erect bus shelters within their respective estates at their own expense in the same manner as these developers are required to construct roads which are subsequently taken over by the Public Works Department. Does the Minister not agree that his Ministry will be able to assist in improving the level of services of public transport by requiring these developers, which I have included the statutory bodies as well, to provide the supporting facilities for public transport?

    Mr Barker: That is certainly a matter that will be considered at least by the Housing and Development Board; I do not know about the Jurong Town Corporation. But at the moment the Housing and Development Board itself is providing termini for buses, and it pays for them. This suggestion is only taking the matter a step further.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Priority allocation of flats)


    7. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board (a) how many statutory boards there are whose employees, who are provided with quarters, are given priority of allocation of the Board's flats on their retirement; and (b) whether this priority is also accorded to employees of the institutes of higher learning or if the Board will consider extending it to them.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, priority allocation of Housing and Development Board flats is granted to all statutory hoard employees and Government servants who are provided with quarters and are required to vacate them when they retire front service. This priority is not accorded to employees of the institutes of higher learning nor is it intended to extend this privilege to them. Apart from the University of Singapore, institutes of higher learning also include the Nanyang University, Ngee Ann Technical College and the Singapore Polytechnic.
